	476.0f,
	477.0f,
	478.0f,
	479.0f,
	480.0f,
	481.0f,
	482.0f,
	483.0f,
	484.0f,
	485.0f,
	486.0f,
	487.0f,
	488.0f,
	489.0f,
	490.0f,
	491.0f,
	492.0f,
	493.0f,
	494.0f,
	495.0f,
	496.0f,
	497.0f,
	498.0f,
	499.0f,
	500.0f,
	501.0f
};

/**
* Evaluates a rational function (i.e., the ratio of two polynomials described by the coefficients stored in \\(P\\) and \\(Q\\)).
*
* ## Notes
*
* -   Coefficients should be sorted in ascending degree.
* -   The implementation uses [Horner's rule][horners-method] for efficient computation.
*
* [horners-method]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horner%27s_method
*
* @param x    value at which to evaluate the rational function
* @return     evaluated rational function
*/
static float rational123( const float x ) {
	float s1;
	float s2;
	float ax;
	float ix;
	int i;

	if ( x == 0.0f ) {
		return 0.0f;
	}
	if ( x < 0.0f ) {
		ax = -x;
	} else {
		ax = x;
	}
	if ( ax <= 1.0f ) {
		s1 = RATIONAL123_COEFFICIENTS_P[ 501 ];
		s2 = RATIONAL123_COEFFICIENTS_Q[ 501 ];
		for ( i = 501-1; i >= 0; i-- ) {
			s1 *= x;
			s2 *= x;
			s1 += RATIONAL123_COEFFICIENTS_P[ i ];
			s2 += RATIONAL123_COEFFICIENTS_Q[ i ];
		}
	} else {
		ix = 1.0f / x; // use inverse to avoid overflow
		s1 = RATIONAL123_COEFFICIENTS_P[ 0 ];
		s2 = RATIONAL123_COEFFICIENTS_Q[ 0 ];
		for ( i = 1; i <= 501; i++ ) {
			s1 *= ix;
			s2 *= ix;
			s1 += RATIONAL123_COEFFICIENTS_P[ i ];
			s2 += RATIONAL123_COEFFICIENTS_Q[ i ];
		}
	}
	return s1 / s2;
}
